topics.title: Founder persistence and fundraising rejection resilience
topics.summary: Keith opens with lessons from DoorDash’s precarious runway and repeated VC rejections: persistence is essential, and “it only takes one yes.” He contrasts founder vs. non-founder mindset—founders find a way to keep going.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Keith’s unusual leadership path across many DoorDash functions (legal, HR, marketing, support, BD/corp dev) and prior role at Uber. Sets expectations for a wide-ranging conversation on leadership and culture.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for OneSchema (CSV importing) and Amplitude (product analytics), followed by Keith’s welcome to the show.

topics.title: Calling a candidate an asshole—culture fit
topics.summary: Keith recounts initially flagging Ryan Sokol as a “jerk,” then directly confronting him at dinner to test self-awareness and receptiveness to feedback. The story illustrates DoorDash’s “no politics, no asshole” bar and how direct feedback can reveal true culture fit.

topics.title: DoorDash culture: humility, customer obsession, bias to action
topics.summary: Keith shares culture-defining stories: founders assembling cheap champagne flutes after a tough Series D, and the WeDash program requiring employees to deliver orders. A standout anecdote features Keith’s daughter calling Tony Xu about a broken delivery experience—Tony immediately escalates and drives a fix.

topics.title: WeDash details and using it to screen hires
topics.summary: They discuss how often employees dash (at least quarterly) and Keith’s monthly participation, plus examples of bugs found through real deliveries. Keith explains alternatives (e.g., support) and how the requirement attracts humble, customer-obsessed talent while filtering out poor fits.

topics.title: Leading unfamiliar functions: generalists, autonomy, hiring experts
topics.summary: Keith explains how he credibly led many teams despite not being a domain expert, including Tony’s “Range” philosophy: generalists can drive 10x outcomes by challenging defaults. His approach centers on hiring true experts, being transparent about gaps, and then getting out of their way.

topics.title: Scaling culture with a “How to work with Keith” doc
topics.summary: Keith describes a written guide to scale expectations and culture during hypergrowth: traits of successful people, his own improvement areas, and commitments to the team. The document helps onboarding, clarifies working norms, and attracts senior talent through transparency.

topics.title: Helping reports find their next job—even outside DoorDash
topics.summary: Keith explains why he actively supports employees’ career moves: it increases trust, reduces surprise attrition, strengthens his long-term manager brand, and can even create boomerangs. He operationalizes it via one-on-ones and by forwarding recruiter outreach to senior reports.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda (docs that combine data and workflows) and a startup credit offer.

topics.title: Unifying exec decisions: empathy, steelmanning, decision clarity
topics.summary: Keith outlines how he helps strong-willed leaders converge: understand motivations, have each side argue the other’s case, and clarify the decision maker and timeline. The goal is healthy debate followed by fast commitment once a call is made.

topics.title: One-on-ones and building a feedback culture
topics.summary: Keith shares tactics for effective one-on-ones: explicitly require upward constructive feedback, create space to give feedback, and close the loop by acting on it. He cites Uber’s T3B3 practice (three positives, three constructive) and emphasizes thanking people and showing changes.

topics.title: Leading through tough times and creating urgency
topics.summary: Keith explains why downturns can strengthen companies: they reveal mission-driven teammates, force discipline on unit economics, and make talent more available. He also discusses how Tony Xu sustains urgency via compounding speed gains and staying hungry—even on IPO day.

topics.title: Pandemic rollercoaster: demand swings, support shutdowns, reliability
topics.summary: Keith recounts early COVID volatility: initial order collapse, then rapid demand doubling, while global support centers shut down and the app crashed on peak nights. Despite operational strain, customer gratitude rose, reinforcing DoorDash’s mission and prompting major restaurant-support decisions.
